docs.lead_paragraph: SCIENTISTS have now made human cells in the test tube grow beyond the usual limit at which they curl up and die. If cells can be made to live indefinitely, can people too be made immortal? It takes a pinch of hubris even to ask the question; myth and religion teach that immortality is reserved for the gods. The many prescriptions proposed for longevity have always turned out to be as illusory as the Fountain of Youth or to hold serious drawbacks for all but the determinedly ascetic. Early castration lengthens life a little; semi-starvation does wonders for laboratory rodents, but no one yet knows if half rations will also extend the human life span.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Cells Unlocked; Longevity's New Lease on Life

docs.abstract: Human search for longevity discussed in light of announcement that biologists have altered human cells in way that alllows them to break Hayflick limit; Leonard Hayflick discovered in 1965 that normal human cells, when cultured in test tube, will divide about 50 times and then die of old age; biologists at Geron Corp and University of Texas Southwestern Medical School refer to their re-engineered cells as 'rejuvenated'; photo of Jeanne Calment of France, who died last year at age 122 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''THIS ain't my grandfather's bar association.'' So began a recent letter to Joshua Pruzansky, a Smithtown lawyer, a letter of which he is particularly proud because, as president of the New York State Bar Association in Albany, Mr. Pruzansky is seeking unprecedented changes from both the Federal and state governments. With more than 60,000 members, the New York State association is the largest voluntary bar association in the United States. Consisting mainly of lawyers, judges, law teachers and non-practicing lawyers, it is an advocate for both the legal profession and the public. Over the last decade, the New York State Bar Association has developed programs addressing a wide range of public concerns, from child abuse and problems of the elderly, to government corruption and the high cost of justice.

headline.main: Q&A/Joshua Pruzansky; Keeping the Bar a Voice for Freedoms

docs.abstract: Interview with Joshua Pruzansky, Smithtown, LI, lawyer who is president of New York Stte Bar Association; says Pruzansky is seeking unprecedented changes from both Federal and state governments on protecting basic freedoms; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF the Asian financial crisis and roller-coaster markets haven't given you enough post-holiday worries, you can always turn your attention to the year 2000 computer crisis. In fact, you should. Less than two years away, a pervasive computer glitch will fully kick in just as the ball drops in Times Square on Jan. 1, 2000. The so-called millennium bug could prove very risky for your personal finances.

headline.main: Can You Crush The Millennium Bug?

docs.lead_paragraph: A Government advisory committee that recommends whether treatments should be covered by Medicare has removed insurance company officials as members after questions were raised about its practice of holding meetings closed to the public. The panel, the Technology Advisory Committee, will let only members who are Government employees into its next meeting in February, said officials at the Health Care Finance Administration, the agency that oversees Medicare and runs the committee.

headline.main: Are H.M.O.'s Better at Cutting Costs or Quality?

docs.lead_paragraph: Blood Supply Low The region is experiencing the most severe blood shortage in more than a decade, and some Westchester hospitals have asked doctors to cancel elective surgery. ''Quite critical,'' was the way Linda Levi, a spokeswoman at the New York Blood Center in Manhattan, described the situation. At the center, which supplies blood to the Hudson Valley, New York City, Long Island and northern and central New Jersey, supplies of Type O Positive blood are especially low: ''Twelve pints is the optimal inventory. We have half that,'' Ms. Levi said.
docs.abstract: Blood banks in Westchester County, NY, and elsewhere in New York region face severe shortages; Pelham Manor Ethics Board finds Police Chief Dennis Carroll did not violate any rules by buying personal vehicle from car dealership supplying municipality with police vehicles; New York Office of Children and Family Services gives high ratings to Westchester program handling child abuse; Westchester Medical Center, Valhalla, has become public benefit corp, free from county oversight, making it easier for it to form alliances with other hospitals and health insurers; Westchester's countywide office vacancy rate inched up in 1997 to 16.5 percent, from 16.1 percent, although rate fell in some areas (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT the age of 80, Rena Hamelfarb describes herself as basically healthy, although the medical bills have begun to pour in, mainly for an ophthalmologist and a dentist. ''I must have spent $15,000 on my teeth in the last five years,'' Ms. Hamelfarb said. She waited three years for her name to be reached on the waiting list for an apartment at James Lenox House, a 22-year-old residence for the elderly at 49 East 73d Street, and has lived there for two years. There is no communal meal service at Lenox House, and the limited staff is prepared only in an informal way to help tenants arrange for personal services when they need them.

headline.main: Planning an Upper East Side Building for the Elderly

docs.abstract: Health Advocates for Older People, nonprofit group, plans to build services-enhanced residence for middle-income people in their 70's and 90's on Upper East Side, New York City; will offer two meals a day and limited services as part of basic rent and added personal services on fee-for-service basis; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If dodging bill collectors were an Olympic sport, Herbert Weiss would have already earned a fistful of gold medals. No matter how many times the telephone rings, no matter how persistent the caller, Mr. Weiss is unmoved, and an impish grin remains fixed on his face. ''They're not going to get me,'' said Mr. Weiss, a 62-year-old Holocaust survivor who owes nearly $100,000 in medical bills. Advancing diabetes has choked circulation and sensation in his limbs, leaving them susceptible to infections and to gangrene. Over the last four years, doctors have removed his right leg and the toes on his left foot, which has in turn removed much of his independence. ''Did I mention that I also had a few heart attacks?'' he asked last week. Mr. Weiss, seated in a wheelchair in his apartment in Queens, was wearing an elegant striped shirt with a mustard tie and charcoal flannel trousers. ''With me, there's never a dull moment,'' he said.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Survivor Still Matches Wits With Bill Collectors

docs.abstract: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Herbert Weiss, Queens man with advancing diabetes who owes nearly $100,000 in medical bills; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will. While he has sometimes been questioned, his control has never been seriously challenged. He has never hesitated to use force, favoritism or political manipulation. But in the last decade, it has been Indonesia's remarkable prosperity -- built partly on a cascade of foreign investment -- that has cemented his control.

headline.main: Sudden Weakness Aside, Suharto Looks to Outlast Economic Crisis

docs.abstract: World financial markets have brought Indonesia's currency and $225 billion economy to brink of collapse; opponents of Pres Suharto, who has ruled Indonesia for 32 years, have called for him to step down; Suharto has agreed to allow International Monetary Fund to direct minute details of his country's daily life; he has agreed to break up cartels that have made his family and loyalists millionaires; while Suharto's future seems suddenly in play, it is far from sure that Indonesia's economic crisis marks beginning of end of his long rule (M)
docs.snippet: For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will.    While he has sometimes been questioned, his control has never been seriously challenged....

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and SETH MYDANS

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST summer, Wade Costello was happy when her father was admitted to the Decker wing of 3030 Park, a nursing home complex at that address in Bridgeport. Previously only residents of the complex had been admitted to the wing, but with the help of a lawyer who specializes in issues of the elderly, Mrs. Costello's father was admitted on an emergency basis. 3030 Park has an excellent reputation and Mrs. Costello said it deserves it. The complex is cheerful and clean, and its nursing staff is caring. ''3030 Park was the perfect solution,'' Mrs. Costello said.

headline.main: Changing Market In Care of Elderly

docs.abstract: Changes in health care industry are affecting long-term care for elderly in Connecticut; Legislature names committee to consider tightening regulation of continuing care retirement communities, including complex in Bridgeport (M)
